en.use:
Used in patients presenting with stereotypical episodes of vomiting suggestive of cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS) with at least two discrete episodes in the past 6 months. The diagnosis of CVS should be made by clinical history, physical examination, minimal laboratory tests, and a gastric emptying study.

- Helps to make a diagnosis of cyclic vomiting syndrome when appropriate workup of upper GI symptoms is nondiagnostic.
- Helps to distinguish symptoms from other functional disorders of nausea and vomiting, such as cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome and chronic nausea and vomiting syndrome.
- Helps to guide management of vomiting symptoms.
en.misuse:
Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though CVS may be present:

- Signs or symptoms of GI bleeding
- Unexplained iron deficiency anemia
- Unintentional weight loss
- Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam
- Family history of gastric cancer and no recent upper endoscopy
- Dysphagia
- Persistent vomiting
- Neurologic symptoms

gt0001.text: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Cyclic Vomiting Syndrome
gt0001.description:
Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of cyclic vomiting syndrome.

To fulfill the Rome IV criteria for cyclic vomiting syndrome,* patient must have the following:

- Stereotypical episodes of vomiting regarding onset (acute) and duration (<1 week).
- ≥3 discrete episodes in the prior year and 2 episodes in the past 6 months, occurring ≥1 week apart.
- Absence of vomiting between episodes, but other milder symptoms can be present between cycles.

*History or family history of migraine headaches may support diagnosis.
